title: 112_s2319
content: The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012, also known as the IPAWS Modernization Act, amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System. The Administrator is required to modernize and implement the public alert and warning system to provide timely warnings for natural disasters, wars, terrorism, and other hazards to public safety. The Administrator must establish common alerting protocols, adapt communications based on location and risks, provide information to individuals with disabilities and limited English proficiency, and conduct training for the public alert and warning system. The public alert and warning system includes exercises, nationwide tests, and training programs for government officials. Public education efforts are also conducted to inform various entities and the public. The public alert and warning system coordinates with the National Terrorism Advisory System and consults with private sector entities and government authorities. The public alert and warning system must incorporate multiple communication systems and technologies, adapt to future technologies, and provide accessible alerts to individuals with disabilities, limited English proficiency, and nonresident visitors. It coordinates with the National Terrorism Advisory System and consults with private sector entities and government authorities. The public alert and warning system aims to reach visitors and tourists, improve alerts in remote areas, and provide redundant alert mechanisms. The Administrator may conduct pilot programs to demonstrate feasibility, and limitations are in place for message transmission. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 requires the Administrator to provide performance reports on the public alert and warning system annually. The reports establish performance goals, describe the system's performance, and detail the technology used for alerts and warnings. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 mandates annual performance reports on the public alert and warning system. The reports cover alerts and warnings issued, measures for individuals with disabilities and limited English proficiency, training, tests, exercises, challenges, necessary improvements, and system performance analysis. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 requires the Administrator of FEMA to establish a subcommittee for the National Advisory Council to ensure the system meets performance goals. The Administrator must submit reports to specific congressional committees as mandated by the Act. The Integrated Public Alert and Warning System Modernization Act of 2012 mandates the establishment of a Subcommittee under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Subcommittee includes members such as the Chairman of the FCC, the Administrator of NOAA, the Assistant Secretary for Communications and Information of the Department of Commerce, and the Under Secretary for Science and Technology. The Subcommittee under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 includes members such as the Under Secretary for Science and Technology, the Under Secretary for the National Protection and Programs Directorate, and the Director of the Office of Disability Integration and Coordination of FEMA, along with qualified individuals appointed by the Administrator. The Subcommittee includes representatives from emergency management agencies, response providers, and communication providers, as well as individuals with technical expertise from vendors, developers, and manufacturers in the communications industry. The Subcommittee includes representatives from various industries such as the cellular, cable, and satellite industries, as well as consumer advocates, national organizations for individuals with disabilities, and organizations for individuals with limited English proficiency. Additionally, qualified representatives of other stakeholders and interested parties are also included. The Subcommittee, chaired by the Administrator, must meet within 180 days of the Act's enactment and at least annually thereafter. It can make recommendations for enhancing the public alert system, including protocols and standards. The Subcommittee, chaired by the Administrator, must meet within 180 days of the Act's enactment and at least annually thereafter to assess the public alert and warning system, identify accomplishments and deficiencies, and make recommendations for improvements. This includes recommendations for a system that can adapt communication distribution based on location, risks, and various technologies, as well as the capability to alert and warn effectively. The public alert and warning system should have the capability to alert individuals with disabilities and limited English proficiency, incorporate multiple communication technologies, adapt to future technologies, encourage proper use by governments, and provide alerts to the largest portion of the affected population. The public alert and warning system should reach the largest portion of the affected population, including visitors and tourists, enhance community preparedness through partnerships, and provide redundant alert mechanisms for widespread communication. The Subcommittee will report to the National Advisory Council on Homeland Security. The Advisory Council established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 must report recommendations to the Administrator. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2013 through 2017. The Department of Commerce and the Federal Communications Commission's authority is not affected by this section.
